executive_summary: Operators in the Cable Networks industry produce and acquire programs that it then supplies to third-party broadcasters for dissemination. The industry has responded to waning TV subscriptions by expanding its premium content offerings over the five years to 2021. In addition, the industry also derives a significant portion of its revenue from advertising fees. Therefore, industry revenue benefited as total advertising expenditure in the US rose to unprecedented levels. However, the rise in online streaming services and the recent spread of COVID-19 (coronavirus) deterred industry performance. Overall, IBISWorld projects industry revenue will stagnate at $94.0 billion over the five years to 2021 despite growing 1.1% in 2021 as the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic gives way to an economic recovery.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Viewership increase for cable news channels
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: According to Comscore TV Essentials® data, viewership increased for CNN, Fox News and MSNBC, three major cable news channels, in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic and people staying at home.
Social unrest during the summer of 2020 and the recent presidential election have also likely contributed to the boost in live TV viewership.

Overall, IBISWorld expects industry revenue to stagnate at $94.0 billion over the five years to 2021, but is forecast to increase 1.1% in 2021 alone in line with an expected economic recovery from the effect of the coronavirus pandemic.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2026, IBISWorld anticipates the Cable Networks industry will experience slight growth as the COVID-19 pandemic subsides and a broad economic recovery bolsters industry revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Continued decline in cable TV subscriptions
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The number of cable TV subscriptions is expected to continue falling at an annualized rate of 2.6% to 75.8 million subscriptions over the five years to 2026.
Cable networks are expected to continue embracing digital platforms and streaming services to adapt to changing consumer preferences and offset declines in cable subscriptions.

industry_definition: This industry operates studios and facilities and distributes TV programs on a subscription or fee basis through cable providers and other platforms. Operators include specialty TV cable networks and pay-per-view programming. Programming production and satellite broadcasters are excluded from this industry.
key_trends: The emergence of streaming services has had mixed effects on the industry
Consolidation among cable networks has bolstered network market power
The primary sources of advertising have been changing
Advertising expenditure is a major source of revenue for the industry
The number of cable TV subscriptions is expected to continue falling

market_segmentation.segment_description: According to data from Pew Research, 84.0% of adults over the age of 65 subscribe to a TV package, making them a major market segment for the industry.
Consumers aged 50 to 64 are another significant market segment as they are more likely to have established households and habits of cable TV viewership.
This age group represents 27.4% of industry revenue, though they are less likely to subscribe to cable TV compared to older demographics.
Only 31.0% of people under 30 subscribe to cable TV, preferring streaming services instead. This younger demographic makes up just 12.8% of industry revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: Licensing of rights to broadcast or distribute content is estimated to comprise 51.8% of industry revenue. The industry derives a substantial portion of its total revenue from providing specialty programming and channel services to basic and digital cable operators.
The industry generates an expected 29.0% of its 2021 revenue from selling advertising spots to air on its networks nationally and regionally.
Local advertising is estimated to represent a much smaller share of industry revenue at just 0.8%. Cable networks set aside a small portion of available airtime to be filled by local advertisers.
Network compensation is expected to account for 7.9% of industry revenue in 2021. This segment has been relatively steady as a share of revenue.
The industry also receives 3.9% of its revenue through regional and municipal governments paying to keep certain programming blocks and channels open for public use.
Other industry services are diverse and include: the sale of consumer products, licensing of content libraries, and operation of studio production facilities.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for services provided by the Cable Networks industry is largely driven by demand for new channels, programs and content from cable providers that distribute the content to customers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Consumer demand for channels and programs
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Changes in demand for industry services can therefore be linked to the consumer. Households that pay for cable subscriptions are given basic or premium packages containing numerous channels from cable networks.
The ratings performance of these channels can be determined by data accumulated through cable boxes as well as independent industry trackers, such as Nielsen Holdings PLC.
Cable services are also being increasingly bundled with other telecommunications services, such as internet and telephone services.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Due to the service-based nature of the Cable Networks industry, cable networks do not engage in significant international trade. Cable networks mainly service the domestic market.
However, video channels and programs are also being sold to overseas countries as cable and pay TV services by major operators.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region has the highest concentration of industry establishments at 24.6% due to major networks headquartered there.
The West region, especially California with its ties to the entertainment industry, has 21.8% of establishments.
The Southeast region accounts for 20.4% of industry establishments.
New England has 15.1% of industry establishments due to major media markets like Boston.

regulations_points.regulation_title: FCC regulations on ownership and mergers
regulations_points.regulation_description: The FCC has regulations on horizontal ownership limits and evaluates major cable mergers to prevent monopolies, though some restrictions have been relaxed.
The FCC establishes rules governing program content, prohibiting obscene material and regulating indecent/profane content on cable networks.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Operators in the Cable Networks industry must meet registration requirements and other regulations, creating significant barriers to entry in terms of both the time and money required to adhere to federal broadcasting rules.

barriers_points.barrier_title: High costs of delivering high-quality content
barriers_points.barrier_description: There are also high and recurring costs associated with establishing a new cable network, particularly in delivering the consistently high-quality product that cable distributors and the subscribers demand.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition based on diversity, quality, pricing and consistency of programming
basis_points.basis_description: The Cable Networks industry primarily competes on the basis of diversity, quality, pricing structure and consistency of programming, which caters to the needs of both general subscribers and niche markets.

basis_points.basis_title: Creative talent, popular content and marketing are key success factors
basis_points.basis_description: Success in cable programming relies on creative talent, popular content, aggressive marketing and careful consideration for the types of programming consumers desire most.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 4 players account for 66.9% market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: The Cable Networks industry exhibits a moderate to high level of market share concentration, with the top four players estimated to represent 66.9% of industry revenue in 2021.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Limits on vertical integration between networks and distributors
concentration_points.concentration_description: There are, however, Federal Communications Commission limits on the extent of vertical integration between the cable networks and distributors.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Programming costs, which make up the bulk of purchases, have increased in recent years as TV production companies have gained access to new markets for content, namely streaming services.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Cable Networks industry is estimated to have a high level of capital intensity, mostly due to technological investments that the industry is incurring to enhance the content and delivery service of the networks' programs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Capital costs for facility and equipment upgrades
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital costs mainly encompass spending on facility upgrades and software updates, but also include recent program enhancements to HD, 3D and 4K display capabilities.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Stable pricing models and subscriber numbers
volatility_points.volatility_description: Operator revenue is contingent on industry pricing models and cable subscriptions, which have been relatively stable over the past five years despite some shifts to alternative media.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Video streaming services have disrupted the traditional cable network business model, as consumers are increasingly cutting the cord and opting for streaming services over cable packages.
TV manufacturers have shifted focus to ultra-HD and 4K displays, requiring cable networks to update filming, production and delivery technologies to support the new formats.

FAQs.question: How have changes in individual consumer electronic use changed your operations?
FAQs.answer: Increased consumer viewing of video content outside of traditional television left the industry struggling to maintain the value of its ad placements.

FAQs.question: How reliant is your company on advertising revenue?
FAQs.answer: On average, cable networks generate nearly one-third of total revenue from selling advertising spots.

FAQs.question: Does the Cable Networks industry receive any government assistance?
FAQs.answer: The Cable Networks industry does not receive any direct or special federal government assistance. Some states and municipalities do provide tax and monetary incentives for TV production; however, such assistance is usually more applicable to the TV Production industry. The Cable Networks industry does receive assistance from the National Cable and Telecommunications Association (NCTA) which represents the entire cable and telecommunications industry.

FAQs.question: How has the COVID-19 pandemic affected companies in this industry?
FAQs.answer: Since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, many operators in this industry have also received aid and access to loans from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, which was passed in March 2020 to provide economic relief from the effects of the pandemic. The American Rescue Plan Act, recently passed in March 2021, also contains additional funding for these business assistance programs.

FAQs.question: How has the COVID-19 pandemic impacted advertising revenue for cable networks?
FAQs.answer: Several major players reported a significant reduction in advertising revenue largely due to the postponement and/or cancellation of professional and collegiate sports throughout the coronavirus pandemic.

FAQs.question: Is being located in a major media center beneficial for cable networks?
FAQs.answer: Locating in a major media center such as New York or Los Angeles can boost a company's access to production talent.

FAQs.question: Have cable networks experienced rising wages in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Cable networks are generally not labor-intensive, but wages have remained relatively steady as a share of costs in recent years.

FAQs.question: How have cable networks adapted to changing digital interfaces?
FAQs.answer: Amid a decline in traditional television, many cable networks have established alternative digital channels for their content. While this detracts from revenue earned from industry-relevant activities, companies must stay ahead of the changing business environment to preserve total revenue.

FAQs.question: How have software advances impacted cable network operations?
FAQs.answer: Particularly for companies that engage in in-house production, software advances have greatly diminished costs related to editing and other postproduction services.

FAQs.question: Are cable networks facing antitrust scrutiny?
FAQs.answer: The Justice Department challenged AT&T Inc.'s acquisition of Time Warner Inc. but was overruled, indicating there may be relatively few obstacles to industry consolidation going forward. Nevertheless, the level of regulation is expected to remain significant and the largest companies continue to be under the scope of industry-relevant regulatory bodies.

FAQs.question: How do cable networks stay compliant with regulations?
FAQs.answer: Since this industry does not broadcast over the air, it is not subject to the same FCC regulations that broadcast stations are.

FAQs.question: How do profit margins for major cable networks compare to smaller competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins in the industry are generally very high, and major companies generate margins as much as three times wider than small and midsize operators. Conversely, independent and regional networks may only have a few stations and are, therefore, unable to negotiate the same distribution contracts with cable providers.

FAQs.question: What challenges do cable networks face in financing operations?
FAQs.answer: Profit can be somewhat volatile in the industry because ad sales are dependent on the popularity of programming, which can be difficult to forecast. The currently low interest rate environment provides an opportunity for operators to secure low borrowing costs to finance existing or forthcoming obligations.

FAQs.question: How do cable networks maintain relationships with program distributors?
FAQs.answer: Strong links with satellite and cable program distributors ensure maximum household penetration for new and popular channels. These relationships will prove increasingly important moving forward as the cable industry goes through structural consolidation.

FAQs.question: How can cable networks limit cancellations and maintain appropriate pricing?
FAQs.answer: Operators must maintain appropriate pricing models across basic and value-added services to maximize consumer satisfaction and thus limit cancellations. As more streaming services have come to market and these competitive platforms have become more affordable, industry operators will have to continually monitor its pricing strategy to ensure its services remain relevant.

FAQs.question: How do cable networks maintain relationships with regulators?
FAQs.answer: Companies need to maintain close contact with regulators, particularly the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), and ensure compliance with the many regulations that directly affect industry operations.

FAQs.question: How can cable networks offset declines in cable TV subscriptions?
FAQs.answer: Industry revenue typically moves in line with the number of cable TV subscribers, which represents cable networks' total market size. The number of cable TV subscriptions has fallen consistently since 2010 as more consumers have "cut the cord" and replaced traditional cable with the various streaming services which have come to market.

FAQs.question: How do cable networks distinguish themselves from competitors?
FAQs.answer: <UNKNOWN>

FAQs.question: How do cable networks keep track of and incorporate new technology?
FAQs.answer: Advanced systems and technology developed by upstream and downstream industries such as Wire and Cable Manufacturing and Television Production enable networks to offer their subscribers high-definition and high-quality digital services.

FAQs.question: How do cable networks cater to customers with higher incomes?
FAQs.answer: Consumers with greater disposable income are more likely to switch from basic cable systems to more expensive digital cable systems. Therefore, industry revenue is positively correlated with per capita disposable income since an increase in consumer sentiment would generally lead consumers to purchase more higher value services.
